## Getting the data

Today the code wonâ€™t be that complicated at all. Weâ€™ll first get the data, in JSON, and put it into a dataframe.

``` r
library(jsonlite) #fromJSON -> data.frame
library(httr) # GET/POST
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(wordcloud2)

cisa_response <- httr::GET(url = "https://www.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/feeds/known_exploited_vulnerabilities.json",
content_type_json(), accept_json())
View(rawToChar(cisa_response$content))
kev_list <- fromJSON(txt = rawToChar(cisa_response$content))
kev_df <- kev_list[['vulnerabilities']]
```

And thatâ€™s about it.

## Making it a coding exercise

So far, no real coding challenge. But when trying to make sense of the â€œVulnerability Namesâ€, it became a bit more interesting.

While looking (manually) at the data first, I found out that most vulnerability names end with 2-3 words that somehow help categorize them. Things like â€œmemory corruption vulnerabilityâ€, â€œadobe flash playerâ€, â€œdirectory traversal vulnerabilityâ€â€¦

OK so how can we have a look at the most commonly found 3-words occurrences among the vulnerability names? Using â€œN-gramsâ€.

In text analysis and â€œNatural Language Processingâ€, [N-grams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N-gram) are basically that: things (letters, wordsâ€¦) that occur together in the text. This is very useful for validating texts, propose next words to be typed, things like that.

Anyway, in our case, weâ€™ll look for most common strings of â€œ3 wordsâ€ happening in our vulnerability names (just for fun). And for the visualization, although itâ€™s more â€œfunâ€ than â€œusefulâ€ (a table, like those above, would probably do better for serious workâ€¦), weâ€™ll use a wordcloud (I mean, for this exercise, why not?)

``` r
library(ngram)
ng_words_seq <- paste(unlist(strsplit(tolower(kev_df$vulnerabilityName), " ")), collapse = " ")
ng_list <- ngram(ng_words_seq, n = 3)
wordcloud2(get.phrasetable(ng_list)[, 1:2] %>% filter(freq > 2))
```

Thatâ€™s it (it looks easy, but as it was the first time ever I used that ngram package, I had to [read the documentation](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ngram/vignettes/ngram-guide.pdf) a bit :)).

And here the results:

![](KEV_Vuln_types_wordcloud-1024x644.png){alt=""}

You can tell some things occur more than others (also see Prevalence as explained earlier ;)).

â€œBuffer Overflowâ€, â€œMemory Corruptionâ€, â€œCommand Injectionâ€, â€œPrivilege Escalationâ€, â€œImproper input validationâ€, â€œDirectory Traversalâ€, â€œType Confusionâ€, â€œAccess Controlâ€â€¦

Well, maybe a 2 words N-gram was a better idea after all (and removing â€œvulnerabilityâ€). Letâ€™s try that (just for fun):

``` r
ng_words_seq <- gsub("vulnerability", "", ng_words_seq)
ng_list <- ngram(ng_words_seq, n = 2)
wordcloud2(get.phrasetable(ng_list)[, 1:2] %>% filter(freq > 2))
```

![](KEV_Vuln_types_wordcloud2-1024x640.png){alt=""}

Itâ€™s not much better. So maybe this is not the best approach, but fair enough, a good, quick exercise for today.

## What KEV does not say

Iâ€™ve seen it, more than once, so Iâ€™m going to say it: Itâ€™s **â€œNOT THAT EASYâ€ to match two datasets of software names and versions**. It turns out that some inventory (like this KEV thing) and security products (say some vulnerability management tool for example) will list the SAME SOFTWARE with DIFFERENT NAMES.

It sounds ridiculous, I know, but it goes like this, for instance: One might say â€œMicrosoft Windowsâ€, another one might say â€œMS Win Server 2019â€. This very simple example, times the number of vendors of software, their product names, and versions names, times the number of possible ideas each product vendor comes up withâ€¦ It rapidly becomes rather difficult (for an automated approachâ€¦).

**One solution is to use the â€œCPEâ€** (Common Platform Enumeration â€“ which incidentally was created for just this purpose, see [here](https://nvd.nist.gov/products/cpe)) where possible.

For example, the KEV dataset mentions â€œCVE-2020-1350â€, applicable to *Vendor: Microsoft, Product: Windows*. Thatâ€™s a bit too generic for my taste, most companies have MANY Windows machinesâ€¦ Does this vulnerability affect servers, clientsâ€¦?

One would then need to pivot somewhat, so if you search for the CVE, you easily end up on the MITRE page for it:

<https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-1350>

That still doesnâ€™t give you the info you need, then you keep clicking links from there, and maybe you end up finding what you need here for example:

<https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-1350>

![CPE for CVE](KEV_CVE_CPE-204x300.png){alt="CPE for CVE"}

Â 

Finally: This CVE affects certain (most, recent) versions of Windows Server. Now weâ€™re able to leverage this information and go looking for servers in our network that match this and make sure these are patched.

Iâ€™m pretty sure there will be a downloadable CVE database (actually there seems to be an API from the NIST NVD, so [there](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/data-feeds#APIS) would be a good place to startâ€¦ Maybe Iâ€™ll have some time to look into it in upcoming weeks.), but in the worst case scenario you can always crawl (one-by-one, no brute-forcing there, please, that would be against ethical use of their service) the pages referencing each CVE as you need them. Anyhow.

## Conclusions

First of: No â€œbig surpriseâ€ anywhere with this dataset. As said, itâ€™s clean, clearcut, and just for that Iâ€™m thankful ğŸ˜€

Second of all, we could keep going (there is a column of description, and one of datesâ€¦ So we might want to use that maybe to extrapolate how much active the bad guys are by month, for example â€“ although there are again too many confounding variables to conclude much there from just this datasetâ€¦)

The **key aspect** however of the CISA KEV dataset is its **purpose**: to help organizations (or anyone with some IT gear) to, as they put it on the website, **â€œprioritize remediationâ€.**

And thatâ€™s already an important aspect, as itâ€™s easy in a company to have thousands of devices, with quite a few software products on eachâ€¦ Knowing what to take care of first is a good helping hand.

So once you have the KEV dataset, youâ€™ll need to find the machines that are affected by each corresponding CVE, so that you can actually patch those first.

And as youâ€™ll want to patch ALL your systems at some point, you might ask â€œwhy not do that directlyâ€? Well, sometimes applying patches break stuff. So out of precaution, companies usually patch things in waves, usually by importance/business risk (say â€œCritical patches first, focus on Dev environment first, then low-business-criticality serversâ€¦â€).

All this is saying is: you might want to review your patch waves to make sure you patch the systems affected by any of the CVEs in the KEV list sooner rather than later, somehow.
